answers.answer: When my 4-year-old goes through a period when only I will do, I really feel the pinch.  Can't imagine how much harder it would be if he screamed for me if he was ever out of my sight.   Has he ever been traumatized by anything that you know of, or do you think it is just generalized anxiety?  I guess that in your shoes, I would talk to a counselor, maybe someone from school or someone who specializes in children, to assess where your son might be picking up so much anxiety, and try to work out some steps to help ease the anxiety in general.
has he been around any older children recently, any scay movies he may have seen , what happenings ?

This is anxiety - probably an inherited gene and quite possibly has very little to do with trauma or environment or daily happenings.  Anxiety is usually created by the hyper-activity of the neurotransmitters in the brain - often misinterpreting signals and information received by the senses (ears, eyes, touch, etc).  This is why anxiety tends not to make sense - similar to a child who inherits diabetes - it is not "caused"; it just "is".The place to start is always with the family doctor.  You might wish to google phrases as "anxiety behaviours in children" or "separation anxiety" or "how to help a child with anxiety" or similar words/phrases to better understand this issue.  If anxiety is the problem, then I assure it will not go away nor will your child outgrow it.  But, anxiety is a very common issue and highly treatable.  Usually a multi-modal approach is the recommended procedure (counselling may or may not be part of that plan).  Each child is different in his/her fears and thus must be approached differently.  All the best ...

Do you have any other children? If so, put them two to a room. This is what I did with my four. They like to have company when they are little, and some need this more than others. And some get nightmares for no discernible reason. My son did and we never knew why.
